title: Build Server for Continuous Integration
body:
In #212 we started discussing that a build server would be very helpful for a number of reasons:

* Continous Integration: Build the project and run the tests upon every push to the repository
* Verify pull requests: Build pull requests before we merge them to verify they don't break anything
* Releasing: It would be very helpful if we could deploy snapshots and releases to Sonatype's Maven repositories

"Releasing" will probably be easier once we have a Mavenized build.

title: Flexible ParallelComputer
Flexible ParallelComputer
Remove @Deprecated from MethodRule and related methods.
body:
Many developers are legitimate reasons to stick with MethodRule and the JUnit team has
no plans to remove support for MethodRule, so removing the @Deprecated annotations
from MethodRule and methods that use MethodRule.

title: Add 'test' rule to build.xml
body:
The new Ant 'test' rule is for running the tests quickly
It will run the tests without doing a clean or creating jars.

title: Adjust testwatcher skipped to handle failures correctly
body: As a result of the recent merge of the changes by davidhart82 and me the skipped() method I introduced now misses a failure handling if the skipped() method itself fails. In parallel to the failure handling introduced by davidhart82 I adjusted the call to skipped() and also added a test for it.

title: Issue #426 Applied new coding style
body: Applied the new coding style to the code base for issue #426.

title: Flexible ParallelComputer
body:
The ParallelComputer with unlimited Thread pool size is not enugh.

Thus I added methods with parameters where the user can change the Thread pool as he likes.

Opened discussion #518 and got the consensus to update ParallelComputer.

methods(ExecutorService)
classes(ExecutorService)
classesAndMethodsUnbounded()
classesAndMethodsBounded(int nThreads)
classesAndMethods(ThreadPoolExecutor)
classesAndMethods(ThreadPoolExecutor pool, int minConcurrentMethods)
classesAndMethods(ExecutorService poolClasses, ExecutorService poolMethods)

body: Should be emerged immediately before 4.11 is released.

See https://issues.sonatype.org/browse/OSSRH-4501 for rationale.

title: Change to Markdown extension for ease of viewing
body:
It's much easier to read when GitHub converts the Markdown for us:
https://github.com/marcphilipp/junit/blob/release-notes-file-extension/doc/ReleaseNotes4.11.md

title: Parameters method should be invoked after BeforeClass/ClassRules
body:
My use case: I want to open an expensive resource, and then use the data within to generate my parameters. 

Currently, there is no way except in the body of a `@Parameters`-annotated method to specify setup that occurs before the parameters are returned. It seems more in keeping with the design of JUnit to handle this in `@BeforeClass` and `@ClassRules` code, so these should probably run before `@Parameters` methods.

title: fixed and improved Java Concurrency in RunNotifier
body:
I found several Java Concurrency issues in JUnit for parallel testing.
RunNotifier is the first issue.

Problems:

+ synchronizedList(new ArrayList()) is an old construction which has a problem with the new Java Memory Model since Java 1.5. The constructor ArrayList() does not have thread-safe context.
There are other modern totally thread-safe collections like CopyOnWriteArrayList, etc.
+ all the operations, except for addListener() removeListener() and addFirstListener(), might be non-blocking -still making the progress because of only reading the content of fListeners;
+ the operations addListener() removeListener() and addFirstListener() modify the content of fListeners and therefore must be blocking.
+ Reentrant locks use to be faster than traversing across all application threads via synchronized.

Reason to use locks in run():
We must not use iterator snapshot via CopyOnWriteArrayList in run() without synchronization, because the fireTestFailures() must operate on yet non-removed listeners. Therefore run() must use mutual exclusion with addListener() removeListener() and addFirstListener().

title: Allow the array returned by a @DataPoints-annotated method to contain null values
body:
A `@DataPoints`-annotated array field may contain `null` values. Currently, a similarly-annotated method may not: instead the method is _silently_ ignored due to a swallowed `NullPointerException` (see also #449).

This pull request aims to bring support for  `@DataPoints`-methods to the same level as  `@DataPoints`-fields. If accepted, it would be highly appreciated if it can be merged in time for the final release of JUnit 4.11.

title: Create a Rule-like structure that can replicate the behavior of Parameterized without using a custom runner
body: Highly speculative at this point.

title: Incompatibility with Java 5
body:
Morning,
after download JUnit source project and (try) compile, I receive a compilation error.
Commit 41e5c7ed5f82b5a588828584c3ac765b40a76cea (https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/commit/41e5c7ed5f82b5a588828584c3ac765b40a76cea#src/main/java/org/junit/experimental/ParallelComputer.java) inserted a reference to TimeUnit that only exists in Java 1.6.
I changed the JRE version on my local project and everything works, but i believe than JUnit framework is still Java 5 compatible.

I hope I helped. =)

title: Declare the hamcrest-core dependency as "optional".
body:
I suggest to declare the hamcrest maven dependency as `optional` (see [here](http://maven.apache.org/pom.html#Dependencies) for further details). This makes it easier for projects to use different hamcrest versions. Additionally, if a project does not use hamcrest at all, it won't get hamcrest into it's classpath when adding a dependency to JUnit.

If I had to use a different hamcrest version, the dependency declaration would look something like this:

    <dependency>
      <groupId>junit</groupId>
      <artifactId>junit</artifactId>
      <version>4.11-beta-1</version>
      <scope>test</scope>
      <exclusions>
        <exclusion>
          <artifactId>hamcrest-core</artifactId>
          <groupId>org.hamcrest</groupId>
        </exclusion>
      </exclusions>
    </dependency>
    <!-- hamcrest-library depends on hamcrest-core -->
    <dependency>
      <groupId>org.hamcrest</groupId>
      <artifactId>hamcrest-library</artifactId>
      <version>some-other-version</version>
      <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>

With the hamcrest dependency being optional, there is no need to exclude it from the JUnit dependency (*). If I don't want to use hamcrest at all, I can just omit the dependency to hamcrest-library. JUnit will still be fully functional with the exception that `assertThat()` cannot be called without getting a compile error.

A drawback to the `optional` declaration is that existing projects using hamcrest will not compile anymore if they don't explicitely declare a dependency to one of the hamcrest libraries. But since many projects using hamcrest have a dependency to other hamcrest libraries (e.g. hamcrest-all or hamcrest-library which all have a dependency to hamcrest-core), these compile errors should not occur very often.


(*) In simple single-module projects, there is no need for the exclusion since the "nearest" declared dependency wins. But in more complicated project setups there are some constellations where maven resolves the wrong hamcrest version.

title: Deleting Deprecated methods/clases ?
body:
Would it be possible to make an entire cleanup on @Deprecated in some of the future releases ?
If yes, then the version would have to be changed, which in maven terminology of versioning means version 5.x.

title: Parametrized tests
body:
Parameterized tests

Like TestNG, it is possible to specify a data provider for a specific test

title: add @SuppressWarnings("static-method") to org.junit.Test
body:
Eclipse warns that @Test methods can be static. org.junit.Test should be annotated with @SuppressWarnings to disable that warning in eclipse.

more information https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=353394

title: Toward multi-module JUnit: separate assertion mechanisms from core
body:
Assertions and assumptions form implicit contracts between JUnit tests and test runners. There are several ways to satisfy the assertion contract that don't need to get Hamcrest involved at all. To satisfy the assumption contract, you have to use org.junit.Assume, or construct instances of the internal AssumptionViolatedException and bring in Hamcrest as a dependency. I think it'd be a good idea to tease out Assert/Assume, and anything else that helps test writers express test outcomes (matchers, maybe?) into another library that depends on Hamcrest, and get Hamcrest out of JUnit's core.

I'm imagining JUnit becoming a multi-module project (much like Hamcrest is!) with a "core" (annotations for methods, the internal machinery for running tests and stuff for writers of test runners), "assertions", "runners" (specific runners like Suite, Categories, Parameterized, etc. that leverage machinery from the core but needn't  be in the core itself)...maybe more.

I wouldn't anticipate doing this for 4.x, but might necessitate a new major version.

title: Pull Request -- Issue #144
body:
Added additional annotation attribute, message, to org.junit.Test to
allow for custom messages to be returned from failed tests with expected
exceptions.

I left existing messages in place if the annotation attribute was not provided.

I did not change nearly as much of the code as identified. I suspect it may be a tab -> space conversion .

title: Implementation of feature to fix #144
body:
Added additional annotation attribute, message, to org.junit.Test to
allow for custom messages to be returned from failed tests with expected
exceptions. Updated BlockJUnit4ClassRunner to support passing along the
message to ExpectedTest which needed to be updated as well.

Left pre-existing messages intact if no custom message was specified in
the Test annotation.

title: org.junit.runner.Result : Treatment Of Long Variables and thread-safe constructor for List
body:
Improvements/Fixes for org.junit.runner.Result concurrency.

There are three principal Java concurrency issues:
+ fields should be final
+ updates for long fRunTime should be atomic
+ constructor for List should have thread-safe context

title: Only @Category tests should be a subject to run in Categories runner
Pull request for issue #144
body:
Added additional public method, `reportMissingExceptionWithMessage`, to `ExpectedException` rule to allow a
the specification of a custom message that would be thrown in the event a
test did not throw the expected exception. If one is not provided the
class falls back to the previous behavior.

title: Final version of release notes for 4.11
body: Includes changes from #519.

title: forked from #450 and improved
body:
Unlike in #450 i did not delete Timeout(int) constructor because it is backward compatibility issue (in class bytecode).

Instead Deprecated such one.

Added other two constructors with params:
+ with long
+ long and TimeUnit

improved tests and to truly realistic javadoc.

Compiled and tested with JDK 5.

title: FailOnTimeout should catch ClosedByInterruptException and InterruptedIOException in same way as InterruptedException
body:
The NIO is using ClosedByInterruptException and Java I/O is using InterruptedIOException for interruptable I/O operations.
This should not be subject to report stack trace.
